24// AIX has jmpbuf redefined as __jmpbuf in /usr/include/sys/context.h
25// which replaces v8's jmpbuf , resulting in undefined symbol errors
26#if defined(V8_OS_AIX) && defined(jmpbuf)
27#undef jmpbuf
28#endif

39// Determine whether we are running in a simulated environment.
40// Setting USE_SIMULATOR explicitly from the build script will force
41// the use of a simulated environment.
42#if !defined(USE_SIMULATOR)
43#if (V8_TARGET_ARCH_ARM64 && !V8_HOST_ARCH_ARM64)
44#define USE_SIMULATOR 1
45#endif
46#if (V8_TARGET_ARCH_ARM && !V8_HOST_ARCH_ARM)
47#define USE_SIMULATOR 1
48#endif
49#if (V8_TARGET_ARCH_PPC && !V8_HOST_ARCH_PPC)
50#define USE_SIMULATOR 1
51#endif
52#if (V8_TARGET_ARCH_PPC64 && !V8_HOST_ARCH_PPC64)
53#define USE_SIMULATOR 1
54#endif
55#if (V8_TARGET_ARCH_MIPS64 && !V8_HOST_ARCH_MIPS64)
56#define USE_SIMULATOR 1
57#endif
58#if (V8_TARGET_ARCH_S390 && !V8_HOST_ARCH_S390)
59#define USE_SIMULATOR 1
60#endif
61#if (V8_TARGET_ARCH_RISCV64 && !V8_HOST_ARCH_RISCV64)
62#define USE_SIMULATOR 1
63#endif
64#if (V8_TARGET_ARCH_RISCV32 && !V8_HOST_ARCH_RISCV32)
65#define USE_SIMULATOR 1
66#endif
67#if (V8_TARGET_ARCH_LOONG64 && !V8_HOST_ARCH_LOONG64)
68#define USE_SIMULATOR 1
69#endif
70#endif

155#if V8_TARGET_ARCH_ARM || V8_TARGET_ARCH_ARM64
156// Set stack limit lower for ARM and ARM64 than for other architectures because:
157// - on Arm stack allocating MacroAssembler takes 120K bytes.
158// See issue crbug.com/405338
159// - on Arm64 when running in single-process mode for Android WebView, when
160// initializing V8 we already have a large stack and so have to set the
161// limit lower. See issue crbug.com/v8/10575
162#define V8_DEFAULT_STACK_SIZE_KB 864
163#elif V8_TARGET_ARCH_IA32
164// In mid-2022, we're observing an increase in stack overflow crashes on
165// 32-bit Windows; the suspicion is that some third-party software suddenly
166// started to consume a lot more stack memory (before V8 is even initialized).
167// So we speculatively lower the ia32 limit to the ARM limit for the time
168// being. See crbug.com/1346791.
169#define V8_DEFAULT_STACK_SIZE_KB 864
170#elif V8_USE_ADDRESS_SANITIZER
171// ASan makes C++ frames consume more stack, so V8 should leave more stack
172// space available in case a C++ call happens. ClusterFuzz found a case where
173// even just 1 KB less than the default stack size would be enough (see
174// crbug.com/1486275); to be more robust towards future CF reports we'll
175// use an even lower limit.
176#define V8_DEFAULT_STACK_SIZE_KB 960
177#else
178// Slightly less than 1MB, since Windows' default stack size for
179// the main execution thread is 1MB.
180#define V8_DEFAULT_STACK_SIZE_KB 984
181#endif
182
183// Helper macros to enable handling of direct C calls in the simulator.
184#if defined(USE_SIMULATOR) && \
185 (defined(V8_TARGET_ARCH_ARM64) || defined(V8_TARGET_ARCH_MIPS64) || \
186 defined(V8_TARGET_ARCH_LOONG64))
187#define V8_USE_SIMULATOR_WITH_GENERIC_C_CALLS
188#define V8_IF_USE_SIMULATOR(V) , V
189#else
190#define V8_IF_USE_SIMULATOR(V)
191#endif // defined(USE_SIMULATOR) && \
192 // (defined(V8_TARGET_ARCH_ARM64) || defined(V8_TARGET_ARCH_MIPS64) || \
193 // defined(V8_TARGET_ARCH_LOONG64))
194
195// Minimum stack size in KB required by compilers.
196constexpr int kStackSpaceRequiredForCompilation = 40;
197
198// In order to emit more efficient stack checks in optimized code,
199// deoptimization may implicitly exceed the V8 stack limit by this many bytes.
200// Stack checks in functions with `difference between optimized and unoptimized
201// stack frame sizes <= slack` can simply emit the simple stack check.
202constexpr int kStackLimitSlackForDeoptimizationInBytes = 256;
203
204// Sanity-check, assuming that we aim for a real OS stack size of at least 1MB.
205static_assert(V8_DEFAULT_STACK_SIZE_KB * KB +
206 kStackLimitSlackForDeoptimizationInBytes <=
207 MB);
208
209// The V8_ENABLE_NEAR_CODE_RANGE_BOOL enables logic that tries to allocate
210// code range within a pc-relative call/jump proximity from embedded builtins.
211// This machinery could help only when we have an opportunity to choose where
212// to allocate code range and could benefit from it. This is the case for the
213// following configurations:
214// - external code space AND pointer compression are enabled,
215// - short builtin calls feature is enabled while pointer compression is not.
216#if (defined(V8_SHORT_BUILTIN_CALLS) && !defined(V8_COMPRESS_POINTERS)) || \
217 defined(V8_EXTERNAL_CODE_SPACE)
218#define V8_ENABLE_NEAR_CODE_RANGE_BOOL true
219#else
220#define V8_ENABLE_NEAR_CODE_RANGE_BOOL false
221#endif
222
223// This constant is used for detecting whether the machine has >= 4GB of
224// physical memory by checking the max old space size.
225const size_t kShortBuiltinCallsOldSpaceSizeThreshold = size_t{2} * GB;

232#endif

235#ifdef V8_DICT_PROPERTY_CONST_TRACKING
236#define V8_DICT_PROPERTY_CONST_TRACKING_BOOL true
237#else

239#endif

241#ifdef V8_EXTERNAL_CODE_SPACE
242#define V8_EXTERNAL_CODE_SPACE_BOOL true
243#else
244#define V8_EXTERNAL_CODE_SPACE_BOOL false
245#endif
246
247// V8_HEAP_USE_PTHREAD_JIT_WRITE_PROTECT controls how V8 sets permissions for
248// executable pages.
249// In particular,
250// 1) when memory region is reserved for code range, the whole region is
251// committed with RWX permissions and then the whole region is discarded,
252// 2) since reconfiguration of RWX page permissions is not allowed on MacOS on
253// ARM64 ("Apple M1"/Apple Silicon), there must be no attempts to change
254// them,
255// 3) the request to set RWX permissions in the execeutable page region just
256// commits the pages without changing permissions (see (1), they were already
257// allocated as RWX and then deommitted),
258// 4) in order to make executable pages inaccessible one must use
259// OS::DiscardSystemPages() instead of using OS::DecommitPages() or setting
260// permissions to kNoAccess because the latter two are not allowed by the
261// MacOS (see (2)).
262//
263// This is applicable only to MacOS on ARM64 ("Apple M1"/Apple Silicon) which
264// has a APRR/MAP_JIT machinery for fast W^X permission switching (see
265// pthread_jit_write_protect).
266//
267// This approach doesn't work and shouldn't be used for V8 configuration with
268// enabled pointer compression and disabled external code space because
269// a) the pointer compression cage has to be reserved with MAP_JIT flag which
270// is too expensive,
271// b) in case of shared pointer compression cage if the code range will be
272// deleted while the cage is still alive then attempt to configure
273// permissions of pages that were previously set to RWX will fail.
274//
275#if V8_HAS_PTHREAD_JIT_WRITE_PROTECT && \
276 !(defined(V8_COMPRESS_POINTERS) && !defined(V8_EXTERNAL_CODE_SPACE))
277#define V8_HEAP_USE_PTHREAD_JIT_WRITE_PROTECT true
278#else
279#define V8_HEAP_USE_PTHREAD_JIT_WRITE_PROTECT false
280#endif
281
282// Protect the JavaScript heap with BrowserEngineKit APIs.
283#if V8_HAS_BECORE_JIT_WRITE_PROTECT && \
284 !(defined(V8_COMPRESS_POINTERS) && !defined(V8_EXTERNAL_CODE_SPACE))
285#define V8_HEAP_USE_BECORE_JIT_WRITE_PROTECT true
286#else
287#define V8_HEAP_USE_BECORE_JIT_WRITE_PROTECT false
288#endif
289
290// Protect the JavaScript heap with memory protection keys.
291#if V8_HAS_PKU_JIT_WRITE_PROTECT && \
292 !(defined(V8_COMPRESS_POINTERS) && !defined(V8_EXTERNAL_CODE_SPACE))
293#define V8_HEAP_USE_PKU_JIT_WRITE_PROTECT true
294#else
295#define V8_HEAP_USE_PKU_JIT_WRITE_PROTECT false
296#endif
297
298// Determine whether tagged pointers are 8 bytes (used in Torque layouts for
299// choosing where to insert padding).
300#if V8_TARGET_ARCH_64_BIT && !defined(V8_COMPRESS_POINTERS)
301#define TAGGED_SIZE_8_BYTES true
302#else
303#define TAGGED_SIZE_8_BYTES false
304#endif

306#if defined(V8_OS_WIN) && defined(V8_TARGET_ARCH_X64)
307#define V8_OS_WIN_X64 true
308#endif

310#if defined(V8_OS_WIN) && defined(V8_TARGET_ARCH_ARM64)
311#define V8_OS_WIN_ARM64 true
312#endif

318// Support for floating point parameters in calls to C.
319// It's currently enabled only for the platforms listed below. We don't plan
320// to add support for IA32, because it has a totally different approach
321// (using FP stack).
322#if defined(V8_TARGET_ARCH_X64) || defined(V8_TARGET_ARCH_ARM64) || \
323 defined(V8_TARGET_ARCH_MIPS64) || defined(V8_TARGET_ARCH_LOONG64)
324#define V8_ENABLE_FP_PARAMS_IN_C_LINKAGE 1
325#endif

327// Superclass for classes only using static method functions.
328// The subclass of AllStatic cannot be instantiated at all.
329class AllStatic {
330#ifdef DEBUG
331 public:
332 AllStatic() = delete;
333#endif
334};

339constexpr int kMaxInt = 0x7FFFFFFF;
340constexpr int kMinInt = -kMaxInt - 1;
341constexpr int kMaxInt8 = (1 << 7) - 1;
342constexpr int kMinInt8 = -(1 << 7);
343constexpr int kMaxUInt8 = (1 << 8) - 1;
344constexpr int kMinUInt8 = 0;
345constexpr int kMaxInt16 = (1 << 15) - 1;
346constexpr int kMinInt16 = -(1 << 15);
347constexpr int kMaxUInt16 = (1 << 16) - 1;
348constexpr int kMinUInt16 = 0;
349constexpr int kMaxInt31 = kMaxInt / 2;
350constexpr int kMinInt31 = kMinInt / 2;
351
352constexpr uint32_t kMaxUInt32 = 0xFFFFFFFFu;
353constexpr int kMinUInt32 = 0;
354
355constexpr int kInt8Size = sizeof(int8_t);
356constexpr int kUInt8Size = sizeof(uint8_t);
357constexpr int kByteSize = 1;
358constexpr int kCharSize = sizeof(char);
359constexpr int kShortSize = sizeof(short); // NOLINT
360constexpr int kInt16Size = sizeof(int16_t);
361constexpr int kUInt16Size = sizeof(uint16_t);
362constexpr int kIntSize = sizeof(int);
363constexpr int kInt32Size = sizeof(int32_t);
364constexpr int kInt64Size = sizeof(int64_t);
365constexpr int kUInt32Size = sizeof(uint32_t);
366constexpr int kSizetSize = sizeof(size_t);
367constexpr int kFloatSize = sizeof(float);
368constexpr int kDoubleSize = sizeof(double);
369constexpr int kIntptrSize = sizeof(intptr_t);
370constexpr int kUIntptrSize = sizeof(uintptr_t);
371constexpr int kSystemPointerSize = sizeof(void*);
372constexpr int kSystemPointerHexDigits = kSystemPointerSize == 4 ? 8 : 12;
373constexpr int kPCOnStackSize = kSystemPointerSize;
374constexpr int kFPOnStackSize = kSystemPointerSize;
375
376#if V8_TARGET_ARCH_X64 || V8_TARGET_ARCH_IA32
377constexpr int kElidedFrameSlots = kPCOnStackSize / kSystemPointerSize;
378#else
379constexpr int kElidedFrameSlots = 0;
380#endif
381
382constexpr int kDoubleSizeLog2 = 3;
383// The maximal length of the string representation for a double value
384// (e.g. "-2.2250738585072020E-308"). It is composed as follows:
385// - 17 decimal digits, see base::kBase10MaximalLength (dtoa.h)
386// - 1 sign
387// - 1 decimal point
388// - 1 E or e
389// - 1 exponent sign
390// - 3 exponent
391constexpr int kMaxDoubleStringLength = 24;
392
393// Total wasm code space per engine (i.e. per process) is limited to make
394// certain attacks that rely on heap spraying harder.
395// Do not access directly, but via the {--wasm-max-committed-code-mb} flag.
396// Just below 4GB, such that {kMaxWasmCodeMemory} fits in a 32-bit size_t.
397constexpr uint32_t kMaxCommittedWasmCodeMB = 4095;
398
399// The actual maximum code space size used can be configured with
400// --max-wasm-code-space-size. This constant is the default value, and at the
401// same time the maximum allowed value (checked by the WasmCodeManager).
402#if V8_TARGET_ARCH_ARM64 || V8_TARGET_ARCH_LOONG64
403// ARM64 and Loong64 only supports direct calls within a 128 MB range.
404constexpr uint32_t kDefaultMaxWasmCodeSpaceSizeMb = 128;
405#elif V8_TARGET_ARCH_PPC64
406// Branches only take 26 bits.
407constexpr uint32_t kDefaultMaxWasmCodeSpaceSizeMb = 32;
408#else
409// Use 1024 MB limit for code spaces on other platforms. This is smaller than
410// the total allowed code space (kMaxWasmCodeMemory) to avoid unnecessarily
411// big reservations, and to ensure that distances within a code space fit
412// within a 32-bit signed integer.
413constexpr uint32_t kDefaultMaxWasmCodeSpaceSizeMb = 1024;
414#endif
415
416// Align IsolateData to a most common CPU cache line size.
417constexpr size_t kIsolateDataAlignment = 64;
418
419#if V8_HOST_ARCH_64_BIT
420constexpr int kSystemPointerSizeLog2 = 3;
421constexpr intptr_t kIntptrSignBit =
422 static_cast<intptr_t>(uintptr_t{0x8000000000000000});
423constexpr bool kPlatformRequiresCodeRange = true;
424#if (V8_HOST_ARCH_PPC || V8_HOST_ARCH_PPC64) && \
425 (V8_TARGET_ARCH_PPC || V8_TARGET_ARCH_PPC64) && V8_OS_LINUX
426constexpr size_t kMaximalCodeRangeSize = 512 * MB;
427constexpr size_t kMinExpectedOSPageSize = 64 * KB; // OS page on PPC Linux
428#elif V8_TARGET_ARCH_ARM64 || V8_TARGET_ARCH_LOONG64 || V8_TARGET_ARCH_RISCV64
429constexpr size_t kMaximalCodeRangeSize =
430 (COMPRESS_POINTERS_BOOL && !V8_EXTERNAL_CODE_SPACE_BOOL) ? 128 * MB
431 : 256 * MB;
432constexpr size_t kMinExpectedOSPageSize = 4 * KB; // OS page.
433#elif V8_TARGET_ARCH_X64
434constexpr size_t kMaximalCodeRangeSize =
435 (COMPRESS_POINTERS_BOOL && !V8_EXTERNAL_CODE_SPACE_BOOL) ? 128 * MB
436 : 512 * MB;
437constexpr size_t kMinExpectedOSPageSize = 4 * KB; // OS page.
438#else
439constexpr size_t kMaximalCodeRangeSize = 128 * MB;
440constexpr size_t kMinExpectedOSPageSize = 4 * KB; // OS page.
441#endif
442#if V8_OS_WIN
443constexpr size_t kMinimumCodeRangeSize = 4 * MB;
444constexpr size_t kReservedCodeRangePages = 1;
445#else
446constexpr size_t kMinimumCodeRangeSize = 3 * MB;
447constexpr size_t kReservedCodeRangePages = 0;
448#endif
449
450// These constants define the total trusted space memory per process.
451constexpr size_t kMaximalTrustedRangeSize = 1 * GB;
452constexpr size_t kMinimumTrustedRangeSize = 32 * MB;
453
454#else // V8_HOST_ARCH_64_BIT
455
456constexpr int kSystemPointerSizeLog2 = 2;
457constexpr intptr_t kIntptrSignBit = 0x80000000;
458#if (V8_HOST_ARCH_PPC || V8_HOST_ARCH_PPC64) && \
459 (V8_TARGET_ARCH_PPC || V8_TARGET_ARCH_PPC64) && V8_OS_LINUX
460constexpr bool kPlatformRequiresCodeRange = false;
461constexpr size_t kMaximalCodeRangeSize = 0 * MB;
462constexpr size_t kMinimumCodeRangeSize = 0 * MB;
463constexpr size_t kMinExpectedOSPageSize = 64 * KB; // OS page on PPC Linux
464#elif V8_TARGET_ARCH_RISCV32
465constexpr bool kPlatformRequiresCodeRange = false;
466constexpr size_t kMaximalCodeRangeSize = 2048LL * MB;
467constexpr size_t kMinimumCodeRangeSize = 0 * MB;
468constexpr size_t kMinExpectedOSPageSize = 4 * KB; // OS page.
469#else
470constexpr bool kPlatformRequiresCodeRange = false;
471constexpr size_t kMaximalCodeRangeSize = 0 * MB;
472constexpr size_t kMinimumCodeRangeSize = 0 * MB;
473constexpr size_t kMinExpectedOSPageSize = 4 * KB; // OS page.
474#endif
475constexpr size_t kReservedCodeRangePages = 0;
476#endif // V8_HOST_ARCH_64_BIT
477
478static_assert(kSystemPointerSize == (1 << kSystemPointerSizeLog2));
479
480#ifdef V8_COMPRESS_ZONES
481#define COMPRESS_ZONES_BOOL true
482#else
483#define COMPRESS_ZONES_BOOL false
484#endif // V8_COMPRESS_ZONES
485
486// The flag controls whether zones pointer compression should be enabled for
487// TurboFan graphs or not.
488static constexpr bool kCompressGraphZone = COMPRESS_ZONES_BOOL;
489
490#ifdef V8_COMPRESS_POINTERS
491static_assert(
492 kSystemPointerSize == kInt64Size,
493 "Pointer compression can be enabled only for 64-bit architectures");
494
495constexpr int kTaggedSize = kInt32Size;
496constexpr int kTaggedSizeLog2 = 2;
497
498// These types define raw and atomic storage types for tagged values stored
499// on V8 heap.
500using Tagged_t = uint32_t;
501using AtomicTagged_t = base::Atomic32;
502
503#else
504
505constexpr int kTaggedSize = kSystemPointerSize;
506constexpr int kTaggedSizeLog2 = kSystemPointerSizeLog2;
507
508// These types define raw and atomic storage types for tagged values stored
509// on V8 heap.
510using Tagged_t = Address;
511using AtomicTagged_t = base::AtomicWord;
512
513#endif // V8_COMPRESS_POINTERS
514
515static_assert(kTaggedSize == (1 << kTaggedSizeLog2));
516static_assert((kTaggedSize == 8) == TAGGED_SIZE_8_BYTES);
517
518using AsAtomicTagged = base::AsAtomicPointerImpl<AtomicTagged_t>;
519static_assert(sizeof(Tagged_t) == kTaggedSize);
520static_assert(sizeof(AtomicTagged_t) == kTaggedSize);
521
522static_assert(kTaggedSize == kApiTaggedSize);
523
524// TODO(ishell): use kTaggedSize or kSystemPointerSize instead.
525#ifndef V8_COMPRESS_POINTERS
526constexpr int kPointerSize = kSystemPointerSize;
527constexpr int kPointerSizeLog2 = kSystemPointerSizeLog2;
528static_assert(kPointerSize == (1 << kPointerSizeLog2));
529#endif
530
531#ifdef V8_COMPRESS_POINTERS_8GB
532// To support 8GB heaps, all alocations are aligned to at least 8 bytes.
533#define V8_COMPRESS_POINTERS_8GB_BOOL true
534#else
535#define V8_COMPRESS_POINTERS_8GB_BOOL false
536#endif
537
538// This type defines the raw storage type for external (or off-V8 heap) pointers
539// stored on V8 heap.
540constexpr int kExternalPointerSlotSize = sizeof(ExternalPointer_t);
541#ifdef V8_ENABLE_SANDBOX
542static_assert(kExternalPointerSlotSize == kTaggedSize);
543#else
544static_assert(kExternalPointerSlotSize == kSystemPointerSize);
545#endif
546
547// The storage type for pointers referring to CppHeap objects stored on the V8
548// heap.
549constexpr int kCppHeapPointerSlotSize = sizeof(CppHeapPointer_t);
550#ifdef V8_COMPRESS_POINTERS
551static_assert(kCppHeapPointerSlotSize == sizeof(uint32_t));
552#else
553static_assert(kCppHeapPointerSlotSize == kSystemPointerSize);
554#endif
555
556constexpr int kIndirectPointerSize = sizeof(IndirectPointerHandle);
557// When the sandbox is enabled, trusted pointers are implemented as indirect
558// pointers (indices into the trusted pointer table). Otherwise they are regular
559// tagged pointers.
560#ifdef V8_ENABLE_SANDBOX
561constexpr int kTrustedPointerSize = kIndirectPointerSize;
562#else
563constexpr int kTrustedPointerSize = kTaggedSize;
564#endif
565constexpr int kCodePointerSize = kTrustedPointerSize;
566
567// Pointers between trusted objects use compressed pointers with the trusted
568// space base when the sandbox is enabled. Otherwise, they are regular tagged
569// pointers. Either way, they are always kTaggedSize fields.
570constexpr int kProtectedPointerSize = kTaggedSize;
571
572constexpr int kEmbedderDataSlotSize = kSystemPointerSize;
573
574constexpr int kEmbedderDataSlotSizeInTaggedSlots =
575 kEmbedderDataSlotSize / kTaggedSize;
576static_assert(kEmbedderDataSlotSize >= kSystemPointerSize);
577
578constexpr int kExternalAllocationSoftLimit =
579 internal::Internals::kExternalAllocationSoftLimit;
580
581// Maximum object size that gets allocated into regular pages. Objects larger
582// than that size are allocated in large object space and are never moved in
583// memory. This also applies to new space allocation, since objects are never
584// migrated from new space to large object space. Takes double alignment into
585// account.
586//
587// Current value: half of the page size.
588constexpr int kMaxRegularHeapObjectSize = (1 << (kPageSizeBits - 1));
589
590constexpr int kBitsPerByte = 8;
591constexpr int kBitsPerByteLog2 = 3;
592constexpr int kBitsPerSystemPointer = kSystemPointerSize * kBitsPerByte;
593constexpr int kBitsPerSystemPointerLog2 =
594 kSystemPointerSizeLog2 + kBitsPerByteLog2;
595constexpr int kBitsPerInt = kIntSize * kBitsPerByte;
596
597// IEEE 754 single precision floating point number bit layout.
598constexpr uint32_t kBinary32SignMask = 0x80000000u;
599constexpr uint32_t kBinary32ExponentMask = 0x7f800000u;
600constexpr uint32_t kBinary32MantissaMask = 0x007fffffu;
601constexpr int kBinary32ExponentBias = 127;
602constexpr int kBinary32MaxExponent = 0xFE;
603constexpr int kBinary32MinExponent = 0x01;
604constexpr int kBinary32MantissaBits = 23;
605constexpr int kBinary32ExponentShift = 23;
606
607// Quiet NaNs have bits 51 to 62 set, possibly the sign bit, and no
608// other bits set.
609constexpr uint64_t kQuietNaNMask = static_cast<uint64_t>(0xfff) << 51;
610
611constexpr int kOneByteSize = kCharSize;
612
613// 128 bit SIMD value size.
614constexpr int kSimd128Size = 16;
615
616// 256 bit SIMD value size.
617constexpr int kSimd256Size = 32;
618
619// Maximum ordinal used for tracking asynchronous module evaluation order.
620constexpr unsigned kMaxModuleAsyncEvaluatingOrdinal = (1 << 30) - 1;
621
622// FUNCTION_ADDR(f) gets the address of a C function f.
623#define FUNCTION_ADDR(f) (reinterpret_cast<v8::internal::Address>(f))
624
625// FUNCTION_CAST<F>(addr) casts an address into a function
626// of type F. Used to invoke generated code from within C.
627template <typename F>
628F FUNCTION_CAST(uint8_t* addr) {
629 return reinterpret_cast<F>(reinterpret_cast<Address>(addr));
630}
631
632template <typename F>
633F FUNCTION_CAST(Address addr) {
634 return reinterpret_cast<F>(addr);
635}
636
637// Determine whether the architecture uses function descriptors
638// which provide a level of indirection between the function pointer
639// and the function entrypoint.
640#if (V8_HOST_ARCH_PPC || V8_HOST_ARCH_PPC64) && \
641 (V8_OS_AIX || (V8_TARGET_ARCH_PPC64 && V8_TARGET_BIG_ENDIAN && \
642 (!defined(_CALL_ELF) || _CALL_ELF == 1)))
643#define USES_FUNCTION_DESCRIPTORS 1
644#define FUNCTION_ENTRYPOINT_ADDRESS(f) \
645 (reinterpret_cast<v8::internal::Address*>( \
646 &(reinterpret_cast<intptr_t*>(f)[0])))
647#else
648#define USES_FUNCTION_DESCRIPTORS 0
649#endif
650
651constexpr bool StaticStringsEqual(const char* s1, const char* s2) {
652 for (;; ++s1, ++s2) {
653 if (*s1 != *s2) return false;
654 if (*s1 == '\0') return true;
655 }
656}
657
658// -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
659// Declarations for use in both the preparser and the rest of V8.
660
661// The Strict Mode (ECMA-262 5th edition, 4.2.2).
662
663enum class LanguageMode : bool { kSloppy, kStrict };
664static const size_t LanguageModeSize = 2;
665
666inline size_t hash_value(LanguageMode mode) {
667 return static_cast<size_t>(mode);
668}
669
670inline const char* LanguageMode2String(LanguageMode mode) {
671 switch (mode) {
672 case LanguageMode::kSloppy:
673 return "sloppy";
674 case LanguageMode::kStrict:
675 return "strict";
676 }
677 UNREACHABLE();
678}
679
680inline std::ostream& operator<<(std::ostream& os, LanguageMode mode) {
681 return os << LanguageMode2String(mode);
682}
683
684inline bool is_sloppy(LanguageMode language_mode) {
685 return language_mode == LanguageMode::kSloppy;
686}
687
688inline bool is_strict(LanguageMode language_mode) {
689 return language_mode != LanguageMode::kSloppy;
690}
691
692inline bool is_valid_language_mode(int language_mode) {
693 return language_mode == static_cast<int>(LanguageMode::kSloppy) ||
694 language_mode == static_cast<int>(LanguageMode::kStrict);
695}
696
697inline LanguageMode construct_language_mode(bool strict_bit) {
698 return static_cast<LanguageMode>(strict_bit);
699}
700
701// Return kStrict if either of the language modes is kStrict, or kSloppy
702// otherwise.
703inline LanguageMode stricter_language_mode(LanguageMode mode1,
704 LanguageMode mode2) {
705 static_assert(LanguageModeSize == 2);
706 return static_cast<LanguageMode>(static_cast<int>(mode1) |
707 static_cast<int>(mode2));
708}
709
710// A non-keyed store is of the form a.x = foo or a["x"] = foo whereas
711// a keyed store is of the form a[expression] = foo.
712enum class StoreOrigin { kMaybeKeyed, kNamed };
713
714enum class TypeofMode { kInside, kNotInside };
715
716// Whether floating point registers should be saved (and restored).
717enum class SaveFPRegsMode { kIgnore, kSave };
718
719// This enum describes the ownership semantics of an indirect pointer.
720enum class IndirectPointerMode {
721 // A regular reference from one HeapObject to another one through an indirect
722 // pointer, where the referenced object should be kept alive as long as the
723 // referencing object is alive.
724 kStrong,
725 // A reference from one HeapObject to another one through an indirect pointer
726 // with custom ownership semantics. Used for example for references from
727 // JSFunctions to Code objects which follow custom weak ownership semantics.
728 kCustom
729};
730
731// Whether arguments are passed on a known stack location or through a
732// register.
733enum class ArgvMode { kStack, kRegister };
734
735enum class CallApiCallbackMode {
736 // This version of CallApiCallback used by IC system, it gets additional
737 // target function argument which is used both for stack trace reconstruction
738 // in case exception is thrown inside the callback and for callback
739 // side-effects checking by debugger.
740 kGeneric,
741
742 // The following two versions are used for generating calls from optimized
743 // code. They don't need to support side effects checking because function
744 // will be deoptimized when side effects checking is enabled, and they don't
745 // get the target function because it can be reconstructed from the lazy
746 // deopt info in case exception is thrown.
747
748 // This version is used for compiling code when Isolate profiling or runtime
749 // call stats is disabled. The code that uses this version must be created
750 // with a dependency on NoProfilingProtector.
751 kOptimizedNoProfiling,
752
753 // This version contains a dynamic check for enabled profiler and it supports
754 // runtime call stats.
755 kOptimized,
756};
757
758// This constant is used as an undefined value when passing source positions.
759constexpr int kNoSourcePosition = -1;
760
761// This constant is used to signal the function entry implicit stack check
762// bytecode offset.
763constexpr int kFunctionEntryBytecodeOffset = -1;
764
765// This constant is used to signal the function exit interrupt budget handling
766// bytecode offset.
767constexpr int kFunctionExitBytecodeOffset = -1;
768
769// This constant is used to indicate missing deoptimization information.
770constexpr int kNoDeoptimizationId = -1;
771
772// Deoptimize bailout kind:
773// - Eager: a check failed in the optimized code and deoptimization happens
774// immediately.
775// - Lazy: the code has been marked as dependent on some assumption which
776// is checked elsewhere and can trigger deoptimization the next time the
777// code is executed.
778enum class DeoptimizeKind : uint8_t {
779 kEager,
780 kLazy,
781};
782constexpr DeoptimizeKind kFirstDeoptimizeKind = DeoptimizeKind::kEager;
783constexpr DeoptimizeKind kLastDeoptimizeKind = DeoptimizeKind::kLazy;
784static_assert(static_cast<int>(kFirstDeoptimizeKind) == 0);
785constexpr int kDeoptimizeKindCount = static_cast<int>(kLastDeoptimizeKind) + 1;
786inline size_t hash_value(DeoptimizeKind kind) {
787 return static_cast<size_t>(kind);
788}
789constexpr const char* ToString(DeoptimizeKind kind) {
790 switch (kind) {
791 case DeoptimizeKind::kEager:
792 return "Eager";
793 case DeoptimizeKind::kLazy:
794 return "Lazy";
795 }
796}
797inline std::ostream& operator<<(std::ostream& os, DeoptimizeKind kind) {
798 return os << ToString(kind);
799}
800
801// Indicates whether the lookup is related to sloppy-mode block-scoped
802// function hoisting, and is a synthetic assignment for that.
803enum class LookupHoistingMode { kNormal, kLegacySloppy };
804
805inline std::ostream& operator<<(std::ostream& os,
806 const LookupHoistingMode& mode) {
807 switch (mode) {
808 case LookupHoistingMode::kNormal:
809 return os << "normal hoisting";
810 case LookupHoistingMode::kLegacySloppy:
811 return os << "legacy sloppy hoisting";
812 }
813 UNREACHABLE();
814}
815
816static_assert(kSmiValueSize <= 32, "Unsupported Smi tagging scheme");
817// Smi sign bit position must be 32-bit aligned so we can use sign extension
818// instructions on 64-bit architectures without additional shifts.
819static_assert((kSmiValueSize + kSmiShiftSize + kSmiTagSize) % 32 == 0,
820 "Unsupported Smi tagging scheme");
821
822constexpr bool kIsSmiValueInUpper32Bits =
823 (kSmiValueSize + kSmiShiftSize + kSmiTagSize) == 64;
824constexpr bool kIsSmiValueInLower32Bits =
825 (kSmiValueSize + kSmiShiftSize + kSmiTagSize) == 32;
826static_assert(!SmiValuesAre32Bits() == SmiValuesAre31Bits(),
827 "Unsupported Smi tagging scheme");
828static_assert(SmiValuesAre32Bits() == kIsSmiValueInUpper32Bits,
829 "Unsupported Smi tagging scheme");
830static_assert(SmiValuesAre31Bits() == kIsSmiValueInLower32Bits,
831 "Unsupported Smi tagging scheme");
832
833// Mask for the sign bit in a smi.
834constexpr intptr_t kSmiSignMask = static_cast<intptr_t>(
835 uintptr_t{1} << (kSmiValueSize + kSmiShiftSize + kSmiTagSize - 1));
836
837// Desired alignment for tagged pointers.
838constexpr int kObjectAlignmentBits = kTaggedSizeLog2;
839constexpr intptr_t kObjectAlignment = 1 << kObjectAlignmentBits;
840constexpr intptr_t kObjectAlignmentMask = kObjectAlignment - 1;
841
842// Object alignment for 8GB pointer compressed heap.
843constexpr intptr_t kObjectAlignment8GbHeap = 8;
844constexpr intptr_t kObjectAlignment8GbHeapMask = kObjectAlignment8GbHeap - 1;
845
846#ifdef V8_COMPRESS_POINTERS_8GB
847static_assert(
848 kObjectAlignment8GbHeap == 2 * kTaggedSize,
849 "When the 8GB heap is enabled, all allocations should be aligned to twice "
850 "the size of a tagged value.");
851#endif
852
853// Desired alignment for system pointers.
854constexpr intptr_t kPointerAlignment = (1 << kSystemPointerSizeLog2);
855constexpr intptr_t kPointerAlignmentMask = kPointerAlignment - 1;
856
857// Desired alignment for double values.
858constexpr intptr_t kDoubleAlignment = 8;
859constexpr intptr_t kDoubleAlignmentMask = kDoubleAlignment - 1;
860
861// Desired alignment for generated code is 64 bytes on x64 (to allow 64-bytes
862// loop header alignment) and 32 bytes (to improve cache line utilization) on
863// other architectures.
864#if V8_TARGET_ARCH_X64
865constexpr int kCodeAlignmentBits = 6;
866#elif V8_TARGET_ARCH_PPC64
867// 64 byte alignment is needed on ppc64 to make sure p10 prefixed instructions
868// don't cross 64-byte boundaries.
869constexpr int kCodeAlignmentBits = 6;
870#else
871constexpr int kCodeAlignmentBits = 5;
872#endif
873constexpr intptr_t kCodeAlignment = 1 << kCodeAlignmentBits;
874constexpr intptr_t kCodeAlignmentMask = kCodeAlignment - 1;
875
876const Address kWeakHeapObjectMask = 1 << 1;
877
878// The lower 32 bits of the cleared weak reference value is always equal to
879// the |kClearedWeakHeapObjectLower32| constant but on 64-bit architectures
880// the value of the upper 32 bits part may be
881// 1) zero when pointer compression is disabled,
882// 2) upper 32 bits of the isolate root value when pointer compression is
883// enabled.
884// This is necessary to make pointer decompression computation also suitable
885// for cleared weak reference.
886// Note, that real heap objects can't have lower 32 bits equal to 3 because
887// this offset belongs to page header. So, in either case it's enough to
888// compare only the lower 32 bits of a Tagged<MaybeObject> value in order to
889// figure out if it's a cleared reference or not.
890const uint32_t kClearedWeakHeapObjectLower32 = 3;
891
892// Zap-value: The value used for zapping dead objects.
893// Should be a recognizable hex value tagged as a failure.
894#ifdef V8_HOST_ARCH_64_BIT
895constexpr uint64_t kClearedFreeMemoryValue = 0;
896constexpr uint64_t kZapValue = uint64_t{0xdeadbeedbeadbeef};
897constexpr uint64_t kHandleZapValue = uint64_t{0x1baddead0baddeaf};
898constexpr uint64_t kGlobalHandleZapValue = uint64_t{0x1baffed00baffedf};
899constexpr uint64_t kFromSpaceZapValue = uint64_t{0x1beefdad0beefdaf};
900constexpr uint64_t kDebugZapValue = uint64_t{0xbadbaddbbadbaddb};
901constexpr uint64_t kSlotsZapValue = uint64_t{0xbeefdeadbeefdeef};
902constexpr uint64_t kFreeListZapValue = 0xfeed1eaffeed1eaf;
903#else
904constexpr uint32_t kClearedFreeMemoryValue = 0;
905constexpr uint32_t kZapValue = 0xdeadbeef;
906constexpr uint32_t kHandleZapValue = 0xbaddeaf;
907constexpr uint32_t kGlobalHandleZapValue = 0xbaffedf;
908constexpr uint32_t kFromSpaceZapValue = 0xbeefdaf;
909constexpr uint32_t kSlotsZapValue = 0xbeefdeef;
910constexpr uint32_t kDebugZapValue = 0xbadbaddb;
911constexpr uint32_t kFreeListZapValue = 0xfeed1eaf;
912#endif
913
914constexpr int kCodeZapValue = 0xbadc0de;
915constexpr uint32_t kPhantomReferenceZap = 0xca11bac;
916
917// On Intel architecture, cache line size is 64 bytes.
918// On ARM it may be less (32 bytes), but as far this constant is
919// used for aligning data, it doesn't hurt to align on a greater value.
920#define PROCESSOR_CACHE_LINE_SIZE 64
921
922// Constants relevant to double precision floating point numbers.
923// If looking only at the top 32 bits, the QNaN mask is bits 19 to 30.
924constexpr uint32_t kQuietNaNHighBitsMask = 0xfff << (51 - 32);
925
926enum class V8_EXPORT_ENUM HeapObjectReferenceType {
927 WEAK,
928 STRONG,
929};

1074using MaybeObject = MaybeWeak<Object>;

1077// Slots are either full-pointer slots or compressed slots depending on whether
1078// pointer compression is enabled or not.
1079struct SlotTraits {
1080#ifdef V8_COMPRESS_POINTERS
1081 using TObjectSlot = CompressedObjectSlot;
1082 using TMaybeObjectSlot = CompressedMaybeObjectSlot;
1083 using THeapObjectSlot = CompressedHeapObjectSlot;
1084 using TOffHeapObjectSlot =
1085 OffHeapCompressedObjectSlot<V8HeapCompressionScheme>;
1086#ifdef V8_EXTERNAL_CODE_SPACE
1087 using TInstructionStreamSlot =
1088 OffHeapCompressedObjectSlot<ExternalCodeCompressionScheme>;
1089#else
1090 using TInstructionStreamSlot = TObjectSlot;
1091#endif // V8_EXTERNAL_CODE_SPACE
1092#else
1093 using TObjectSlot = FullObjectSlot;
1094 using TMaybeObjectSlot = FullMaybeObjectSlot;
1095 using THeapObjectSlot = FullHeapObjectSlot;
1096 using TOffHeapObjectSlot = OffHeapFullObjectSlot;
1097 using TInstructionStreamSlot = OffHeapFullObjectSlot;
1098#endif // V8_COMPRESS_POINTERS
1099#ifdef V8_ENABLE_SANDBOX
1100 using TProtectedPointerSlot =
1101 OffHeapCompressedObjectSlot<TrustedSpaceCompressionScheme>;
1102#else
1103 using TProtectedPointerSlot = TObjectSlot;
1104#endif // V8_ENABLE_SANDBOX
1105};
1106
1107// An ObjectSlot instance describes a kTaggedSize-sized on-heap field ("slot")
1108// holding an Object value (smi or strong heap object).
1109using ObjectSlot = SlotTraits::TObjectSlot;
1110
1111// A MaybeObjectSlot instance describes a kTaggedSize-sized on-heap field
1112// ("slot") holding Tagged<MaybeObject> (smi or weak heap object or strong heap
1113// object).
1114using MaybeObjectSlot = SlotTraits::TMaybeObjectSlot;
1115
1116// A HeapObjectSlot instance describes a kTaggedSize-sized field ("slot")
1117// holding a weak or strong pointer to a heap object (think:
1118// Tagged<HeapObjectReference>).
1119using HeapObjectSlot = SlotTraits::THeapObjectSlot;
1120
1121// An OffHeapObjectSlot instance describes a kTaggedSize-sized field ("slot")
1122// holding an Object value (smi or strong heap object), whose slot location is
1123// off-heap.
1124using OffHeapObjectSlot = SlotTraits::TOffHeapObjectSlot;
1125
1126// A InstructionStreamSlot instance describes a kTaggedSize-sized field
1127// ("slot") holding a strong pointer to a InstructionStream object. The
1128// InstructionStream object slots might be compressed and since code space might
1129// be allocated off the main heap the load operations require explicit cage base
1130// value for code space.
1131using InstructionStreamSlot = SlotTraits::TInstructionStreamSlot;
1132
1133// A protected pointer is one where both the pointer itself and the pointed-to
1134// object are protected from modifications by an attacker if the sandbox is
1135// enabled. In practice, this means that they are pointers from one
1136// TrustedObject to another TrustedObject as (only) trusted objects cannot
1137// directly be manipulated by an attacker.
1138using ProtectedPointerSlot = SlotTraits::TProtectedPointerSlot;
1139
1140using WeakSlotCallback = bool (*)(FullObjectSlot pointer);
1141
1142using WeakSlotCallbackWithHeap = bool (*)(Heap* heap, FullObjectSlot pointer);
1143
1144// -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1145// Miscellaneous
1146
1147// NOTE: SpaceIterator depends on AllocationSpace enumeration values being
1148// consecutive.
1149enum AllocationSpace {
1150 RO_SPACE, // Immortal, immovable and immutable objects,
1151 NEW_SPACE, // Young generation space for regular objects collected
1152 // with Scavenger/MinorMS.
1153 OLD_SPACE, // Old generation regular object space.
1154 CODE_SPACE, // Old generation code object space, marked executable.
1155 SHARED_SPACE, // Space shared between multiple isolates. Optional.
1156 TRUSTED_SPACE, // Space for trusted objects. When the sandbox is enabled,
1157 // this space will be located outside of it so that objects in
1158 // it cannot directly be corrupted by an attacker.
1159 SHARED_TRUSTED_SPACE, // Trusted space but for shared objects. Optional.
1160 NEW_LO_SPACE, // Young generation large object space.
1161 LO_SPACE, // Old generation large object space.
1162 CODE_LO_SPACE, // Old generation large code object space.
1163 SHARED_LO_SPACE, // Space shared between multiple isolates. Optional.
1164 SHARED_TRUSTED_LO_SPACE, // Like TRUSTED_SPACE but for shared large objects.
1165 TRUSTED_LO_SPACE, // Like TRUSTED_SPACE but for large objects.
1166
1167 FIRST_SPACE = RO_SPACE,
1168 LAST_SPACE = TRUSTED_LO_SPACE,
1169 FIRST_MUTABLE_SPACE = NEW_SPACE,
1170 LAST_MUTABLE_SPACE = TRUSTED_LO_SPACE,
1171 FIRST_GROWABLE_PAGED_SPACE = OLD_SPACE,
1172 LAST_GROWABLE_PAGED_SPACE = TRUSTED_SPACE,
1173 FIRST_SWEEPABLE_SPACE = NEW_SPACE,
1174 LAST_SWEEPABLE_SPACE = TRUSTED_SPACE
1175};
1176constexpr int kSpaceTagSize = 4;
1177static_assert(FIRST_SPACE == 0);
1178
1179constexpr bool IsAnyCodeSpace(AllocationSpace space) {
1180 return space == CODE_SPACE || space == CODE_LO_SPACE;
1181}
1182constexpr bool IsAnyTrustedSpace(AllocationSpace space) {
1183 return space == TRUSTED_SPACE || space == TRUSTED_LO_SPACE ||
1184 space == SHARED_TRUSTED_SPACE || space == SHARED_TRUSTED_LO_SPACE;
1185}
1186constexpr bool IsAnySharedSpace(AllocationSpace space) {
1187 return space == SHARED_SPACE || space == SHARED_LO_SPACE ||
1188 space == SHARED_TRUSTED_SPACE || space == SHARED_TRUSTED_LO_SPACE;
1189}
1190
1191constexpr const char* ToString(AllocationSpace space) {
1192 switch (space) {
1193 case AllocationSpace::RO_SPACE:
1194 return "read_only_space";
1195 case AllocationSpace::NEW_SPACE:
1196 return "new_space";
1197 case AllocationSpace::OLD_SPACE:
1198 return "old_space";
1199 case AllocationSpace::CODE_SPACE:
1200 return "code_space";
1201 case AllocationSpace::SHARED_SPACE:
1202 return "shared_space";
1203 case AllocationSpace::TRUSTED_SPACE:
1204 return "trusted_space";
1205 case AllocationSpace::SHARED_TRUSTED_SPACE:
1206 return "shared_trusted_space";
1207 case AllocationSpace::NEW_LO_SPACE:
1208 return "new_large_object_space";
1209 case AllocationSpace::LO_SPACE:
1210 return "large_object_space";
1211 case AllocationSpace::CODE_LO_SPACE:
1212 return "code_large_object_space";
1213 case AllocationSpace::SHARED_LO_SPACE:
1214 return "shared_large_object_space";
1215 case AllocationSpace::SHARED_TRUSTED_LO_SPACE:
1216 return "shared_trusted_large_object_space";
1217 case AllocationSpace::TRUSTED_LO_SPACE:
1218 return "trusted_large_object_space";
1219 }
1220}
1221
1222inline std::ostream& operator<<(std::ostream& os, AllocationSpace space) {
1223 return os << ToString(space);
1224}
1225
1226enum class AllocationType : uint8_t {
1227 kYoung, // Regular object allocated in NEW_SPACE or NEW_LO_SPACE.
1228 kOld, // Regular object allocated in OLD_SPACE or LO_SPACE.
1229 kCode, // InstructionStream object allocated in CODE_SPACE or CODE_LO_SPACE.
1230 kMap, // Map object allocated in OLD_SPACE.
1231 kReadOnly, // Object allocated in RO_SPACE.
1232 kSharedOld, // Regular object allocated in OLD_SPACE in the shared heap.
1233 kSharedMap, // Map object in OLD_SPACE in the shared heap.
1234 kSharedTrusted, // Trusted objects in TRUSTED_SPACE in the shared heap.
1235 kTrusted, // Object allocated in TRUSTED_SPACE or TRUSTED_LO_SPACE.
1236};
1237
1238constexpr const char* ToString(AllocationType kind) {
1239 switch (kind) {
1240 case AllocationType::kYoung:
1241 return "Young";
1242 case AllocationType::kOld:
1243 return "Old";
1244 case AllocationType::kCode:
1245 return "Code";
1246 case AllocationType::kMap:
1247 return "Map";
1248 case AllocationType::kReadOnly:
1249 return "ReadOnly";
1250 case AllocationType::kSharedOld:
1251 return "SharedOld";
1252 case AllocationType::kSharedMap:
1253 return "SharedMap";
1254 case AllocationType::kTrusted:
1255 return "Trusted";
1256 case AllocationType::kSharedTrusted:
1257 return "SharedTrusted";
1258 }
1259}
1260
1261inline std::ostream& operator<<(std::ostream& os, AllocationType type) {
1262 return os << ToString(type);
1263}
1264
1265// Reason for a garbage collection.
1266//
1267// These values are persisted to logs. Entries should not be renumbered and
1268// numeric values should never be reused. If you add new items here, update
1269// src/tools/metrics/histograms/enums.xml in chromium.
1270enum class GarbageCollectionReason : int {
1271 kUnknown = 0,
1272 kAllocationFailure = 1,
1273 kAllocationLimit = 2,
1274 kContextDisposal = 3,
1275 kCountersExtension = 4,
1276 kDebugger = 5,
1277 kDeserializer = 6,
1278 kExternalMemoryPressure = 7,
1279 kFinalizeMarkingViaStackGuard = 8,
1280 kFinalizeMarkingViaTask = 9,
1281 kFullHashtable = 10,
1282 kHeapProfiler = 11,
1283 kTask = 12,
1284 kLastResort = 13,
1285 kLowMemoryNotification = 14,
1286 kMakeHeapIterable = 15,
1287 kMemoryPressure = 16,
1288 kMemoryReducer = 17,
1289 kRuntime = 18,
1290 kSamplingProfiler = 19,
1291 kSnapshotCreator = 20,
1292 kTesting = 21,
1293 kExternalFinalize = 22,
1294 kGlobalAllocationLimit = 23,
1295 kMeasureMemory = 24,
1296 kBackgroundAllocationFailure = 25,
1297 kFinalizeConcurrentMinorMS = 26,
1298 kCppHeapAllocationFailure = 27,
1299
1300 NUM_REASONS,
1301};
1302
1303static_assert(kGarbageCollectionReasonMaxValue ==
1304 static_cast<int>(GarbageCollectionReason::NUM_REASONS) - 1,
1305 "The value of kGarbageCollectionReasonMaxValue is inconsistent.");
1306
1307constexpr const char* ToString(GarbageCollectionReason reason) {
1308 switch (reason) {
1309 case GarbageCollectionReason::kAllocationFailure:
1310 return "allocation failure";
1311 case GarbageCollectionReason::kAllocationLimit:
1312 return "allocation limit";
1313 case GarbageCollectionReason::kContextDisposal:
1314 return "context disposal";
1315 case GarbageCollectionReason::kCountersExtension:
1316 return "counters extension";
1317 case GarbageCollectionReason::kDebugger:
1318 return "debugger";
1319 case GarbageCollectionReason::kDeserializer:
1320 return "deserialize";
1321 case GarbageCollectionReason::kExternalMemoryPressure:
1322 return "external memory pressure";
1323 case GarbageCollectionReason::kFinalizeMarkingViaStackGuard:
1324 return "finalize incremental marking via stack guard";
1325 case GarbageCollectionReason::kFinalizeMarkingViaTask:
1326 return "finalize incremental marking via task";
1327 case GarbageCollectionReason::kFullHashtable:
1328 return "full hash-table";
1329 case GarbageCollectionReason::kHeapProfiler:
1330 return "heap profiler";
1331 case GarbageCollectionReason::kTask:
1332 return "task";
1333 case GarbageCollectionReason::kLastResort:
1334 return "last resort";
1335 case GarbageCollectionReason::kLowMemoryNotification:
1336 return "low memory notification";
1337 case GarbageCollectionReason::kMakeHeapIterable:
1338 return "make heap iterable";
1339 case GarbageCollectionReason::kMemoryPressure:
1340 return "memory pressure";
1341 case GarbageCollectionReason::kMemoryReducer:
1342 return "memory reducer";
1343 case GarbageCollectionReason::kRuntime:
1344 return "runtime";
1345 case GarbageCollectionReason::kSamplingProfiler:
1346 return "sampling profiler";
1347 case GarbageCollectionReason::kSnapshotCreator:
1348 return "snapshot creator";
1349 case GarbageCollectionReason::kTesting:
1350 return "testing";
1351 case GarbageCollectionReason::kExternalFinalize:
1352 return "external finalize";
1353 case GarbageCollectionReason::kGlobalAllocationLimit:
1354 return "global allocation limit";
1355 case GarbageCollectionReason::kMeasureMemory:
1356 return "measure memory";
1357 case GarbageCollectionReason::kUnknown:
1358 return "unknown";
1359 case GarbageCollectionReason::kBackgroundAllocationFailure:
1360 return "background allocation failure";
1361 case GarbageCollectionReason::kFinalizeConcurrentMinorMS:
1362 return "finalize concurrent MinorMS";
1363 case GarbageCollectionReason::kCppHeapAllocationFailure:
1364 return "CppHeap allocation failure";
1365 case GarbageCollectionReason::NUM_REASONS:
1366 UNREACHABLE();
1367 }
1368}
1369
1370inline std::ostream& operator<<(std::ostream& os,
1371 GarbageCollectionReason reason) {
1372 return os << ToString(reason);
1373}

1375inline size_t hash_value(AllocationType kind) {
1376 return static_cast<uint8_t>(kind);
1377}

1379inline constexpr bool IsSharedAllocationType(AllocationType kind) {
1380 return kind == AllocationType::kSharedOld ||
1381 kind == AllocationType::kSharedMap;
1382}

1384enum AllocationAlignment {
1385 // The allocated address is kTaggedSize aligned (this is default for most of
1386 // the allocations).
1387 kTaggedAligned,
1388 // The allocated address is kDoubleSize aligned.
1389 kDoubleAligned,
1390 // The (allocated address + kTaggedSize) is kDoubleSize aligned.
1391 kDoubleUnaligned
1392};
1393
1394// TODO(ishell, v8:8875): Consider using aligned allocations once the
1395// allocation alignment inconsistency is fixed. For now we keep using
1396// tagged aligned (not double aligned) access since all our supported platforms
1397// allow tagged-aligned access to doubles and full words.
1398#define USE_ALLOCATION_ALIGNMENT_BOOL false

1452bool inline IsBaselineCodeFlushingEnabled(base::EnumSet<CodeFlushMode> mode) {
1453 return mode.contains(CodeFlushMode::kFlushBaselineCode);
1454}

1457 return mode.contains(CodeFlushMode::kFlushBytecode);
1458}

1461 return mode.contains(CodeFlushMode::kStressFlushCode);
1462}

1465 return mode.empty();

1488// unit of compilation. Restriction violations cause a syntax error.

1503// State for inline cache call sites. Aliased as IC::State.
1504enum class InlineCacheState {
1505 // No feedback will be collected.
1506 NO_FEEDBACK,
1507 // Has never been executed.
1508 UNINITIALIZED,
1509 // Has been executed and only one receiver type has been seen.
1510 MONOMORPHIC,
1511 // Check failed due to prototype (or map deprecation).
1512 RECOMPUTE_HANDLER,
1513 // Multiple receiver types have been seen.
1514 POLYMORPHIC,
1515 // Many DOM receiver types have been seen for the same accessor.
1516 MEGADOM,
1517 // Many receiver types have been seen.
1518 MEGAMORPHIC,
1519 // A generic handler is installed and no extra typefeedback is recorded.
1520 GENERIC,
1521};
1522
1523inline size_t hash_value(InlineCacheState mode) {
1524 return base::bit_cast<int>(mode);
1525}
1526
1527// Printing support.
1528inline const char* InlineCacheState2String(InlineCacheState state) {
1529 switch (state) {
1530 case InlineCacheState::NO_FEEDBACK:
1531 return "NOFEEDBACK";
1532 case InlineCacheState::UNINITIALIZED:
1533 return "UNINITIALIZED";
1534 case InlineCacheState::MONOMORPHIC:
1535 return "MONOMORPHIC";
1536 case InlineCacheState::RECOMPUTE_HANDLER:
1537 return "RECOMPUTE_HANDLER";
1538 case InlineCacheState::POLYMORPHIC:
1539 return "POLYMORPHIC";
1540 case InlineCacheState::MEGAMORPHIC:
1541 return "MEGAMORPHIC";
1542 case InlineCacheState::MEGADOM:
1543 return "MEGADOM";
1544 case InlineCacheState::GENERIC:
1545 return "GENERIC";
1546 }
1547 UNREACHABLE();
1548}

1561// Union used for customized checking of the IEEE double types
1562// inlined within v8 runtime, rather than going to the underlying
1563// platform headers and libraries
1564union IeeeDoubleLittleEndianArchType {
1565 double d;
1566 struct {
1567 unsigned int man_low : 32;
1568 unsigned int man_high : 20;
1569 unsigned int exp : 11;
1570 unsigned int sign : 1;
1571 } bits;
1572};
1573
1574union IeeeDoubleBigEndianArchType {
1575 double d;
1576 struct {
1577 unsigned int sign : 1;
1578 unsigned int exp : 11;
1579 unsigned int man_high : 20;
1580 unsigned int man_low : 32;
1581 } bits;
1582};
1583
1584#if V8_TARGET_LITTLE_ENDIAN
1585using IeeeDoubleArchType = IeeeDoubleLittleEndianArchType;
1586constexpr int kIeeeDoubleMantissaWordOffset = 0;
1587constexpr int kIeeeDoubleExponentWordOffset = 4;
1588#else
1589using IeeeDoubleArchType = IeeeDoubleBigEndianArchType;
1590constexpr int kIeeeDoubleMantissaWordOffset = 4;
1591constexpr int kIeeeDoubleExponentWordOffset = 0;
1592#endif

1594// -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1595// Macros
1596
1597// Testers for test.
1598
1599#define HAS_SMI_TAG(value) \
1600 ((static_cast<i::Tagged_t>(value) & ::i::kSmiTagMask) == ::i::kSmiTag)
1601
1602#define HAS_STRONG_HEAP_OBJECT_TAG(value) \
1603 (((static_cast<i::Tagged_t>(value) & ::i::kHeapObjectTagMask) == \
1604 ::i::kHeapObjectTag))
1605
1606#define HAS_WEAK_HEAP_OBJECT_TAG(value) \
1607 (((static_cast<i::Tagged_t>(value) & ::i::kHeapObjectTagMask) == \
1608 ::i::kWeakHeapObjectTag))
1609
1610// OBJECT_POINTER_ALIGN returns the value aligned as a HeapObject pointer
1611#define OBJECT_POINTER_ALIGN(value) \
1612 (((value) + ::i::kObjectAlignmentMask) & ~::i::kObjectAlignmentMask)
1613
1614// OBJECT_POINTER_ALIGN is used to statically align object sizes to
1615// kObjectAlignment (which is kTaggedSize). ALIGN_TO_ALLOCATION_ALIGNMENT is
1616// used for dynamic allocations to align sizes and addresses to at least 8 bytes
1617// when an 8GB+ compressed heap is enabled.
1618// TODO(v8:13070): Consider merging this with OBJECT_POINTER_ALIGN.
1619#ifdef V8_COMPRESS_POINTERS_8GB
1620#define ALIGN_TO_ALLOCATION_ALIGNMENT(value) \
1621 (((value) + ::i::kObjectAlignment8GbHeapMask) & \
1622 ~::i::kObjectAlignment8GbHeapMask)
1623#else
1624#define ALIGN_TO_ALLOCATION_ALIGNMENT(value) (value)
1625#endif
1626
1627// OBJECT_POINTER_PADDING returns the padding size required to align value
1628// as a HeapObject pointer
1629#define OBJECT_POINTER_PADDING(value) (OBJECT_POINTER_ALIGN(value) - (value))
1630
1631// POINTER_SIZE_ALIGN returns the value aligned as a system pointer.
1632#define POINTER_SIZE_ALIGN(value) \
1633 (((value) + ::i::kPointerAlignmentMask) & ~::i::kPointerAlignmentMask)
1634
1635// POINTER_SIZE_PADDING returns the padding size required to align value
1636// as a system pointer.
1637#define POINTER_SIZE_PADDING(value) (POINTER_SIZE_ALIGN(value) - (value))
1638
1639// CODE_POINTER_ALIGN returns the value aligned as a generated code segment.
1640#define CODE_POINTER_ALIGN(value) \
1641 (((value) + ::i::kCodeAlignmentMask) & ~::i::kCodeAlignmentMask)
1642
1643// CODE_POINTER_PADDING returns the padding size required to align value
1644// as a generated code segment.
1645#define CODE_POINTER_PADDING(value) (CODE_POINTER_ALIGN(value) - (value))
1646
1647// DOUBLE_POINTER_ALIGN returns the value algined for double pointers.
1648#define DOUBLE_POINTER_ALIGN(value) \
1649 (((value) + ::i::kDoubleAlignmentMask) & ~::i::kDoubleAlignmentMask)
1650
1651// Prediction hint for branches.
1652enum class BranchHint : uint8_t { kNone, kTrue, kFalse };
1653
1654// Defines hints about receiver values based on structural knowledge.
1655enum class ConvertReceiverMode : unsigned {
1656 kNullOrUndefined, // Guaranteed to be null or undefined.
1657 kNotNullOrUndefined, // Guaranteed to never be null or undefined.
1658 kAny, // No specific knowledge about receiver.
1659
1660 kLast = kAny
1661};
1662
1663inline size_t hash_value(ConvertReceiverMode mode) {
1664 return base::bit_cast<unsigned>(mode);
1665}
1666
1667inline std::ostream& operator<<(std::ostream& os, ConvertReceiverMode mode) {
1668 switch (mode) {
1669 case ConvertReceiverMode::kNullOrUndefined:
1670 return os << "NULL_OR_UNDEFINED";
1671 case ConvertReceiverMode::kNotNullOrUndefined:
1672 return os << "NOT_NULL_OR_UNDEFINED";
1673 case ConvertReceiverMode::kAny:
1674 return os << "ANY";
1675 }
1676 UNREACHABLE();
1677}

1710// Threshold calculated using a microbenckmark.
1711// https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/v8/v8/+/3429210
1712constexpr int kScopeInfoMaxInlinedLocalNamesSize = 75;

1714enum ScopeType : uint8_t {
1715 CLASS_SCOPE, // The scope introduced by a class.
1716 EVAL_SCOPE, // The top-level scope for an eval source.
1717 FUNCTION_SCOPE, // The top-level scope for a function.
1718 MODULE_SCOPE, // The scope introduced by a module literal
1719 SCRIPT_SCOPE, // The top-level scope for a script or a top-level eval.
1720 CATCH_SCOPE, // The scope introduced by catch.
1721 BLOCK_SCOPE, // The scope introduced by a new block.
1722 WITH_SCOPE, // The scope introduced by with.
1723 SHADOW_REALM_SCOPE // Synthetic scope for ShadowRealm NativeContexts.
1724};
1725
1726inline std::ostream& operator<<(std::ostream& os, ScopeType type) {
1727 switch (type) {
1728 case ScopeType::EVAL_SCOPE:
1729 return os << "EVAL_SCOPE";
1730 case ScopeType::FUNCTION_SCOPE:
1731 return os << "FUNCTION_SCOPE";
1732 case ScopeType::MODULE_SCOPE:
1733 return os << "MODULE_SCOPE";
1734 case ScopeType::SCRIPT_SCOPE:
1735 return os << "SCRIPT_SCOPE";
1736 case ScopeType::CATCH_SCOPE:
1737 return os << "CATCH_SCOPE";
1738 case ScopeType::BLOCK_SCOPE:
1739 return os << "BLOCK_SCOPE";
1740 case ScopeType::CLASS_SCOPE:
1741 return os << "CLASS_SCOPE";
1742 case ScopeType::WITH_SCOPE:
1743 return os << "WITH_SCOPE";
1744 case ScopeType::SHADOW_REALM_SCOPE:
1745 return os << "SHADOW_REALM_SCOPE";
1746 }
1747 UNREACHABLE();
1748}

1750// AllocationSiteMode controls whether allocations are tracked by an allocation
1751// site.
1752enum AllocationSiteMode {
1753 DONT_TRACK_ALLOCATION_SITE,
1754 TRACK_ALLOCATION_SITE,
1755 LAST_ALLOCATION_SITE_MODE = TRACK_ALLOCATION_SITE
1756};
1757
1758enum class AllocationSiteUpdateMode { kUpdate, kCheckOnly };
1759
1760// The mips architecture prior to revision 5 has inverted encoding for sNaN.
1761#if (V8_TARGET_ARCH_MIPS64 && !defined(_MIPS_ARCH_MIPS64R6) && \
1762 (!defined(USE_SIMULATOR) || !defined(_MIPS_TARGET_SIMULATOR)))
1763constexpr uint32_t kHoleNanUpper32 = 0xFFFF7FFF;
1764constexpr uint32_t kHoleNanLower32 = 0xFFFF7FFF;
1765#else
1766constexpr uint32_t kHoleNanUpper32 = 0xFFF7FFFF;
1767constexpr uint32_t kHoleNanLower32 = 0xFFF7FFFF;
1768#endif
1769
1770constexpr uint64_t kHoleNanInt64 =
1771 (static_cast<uint64_t>(kHoleNanUpper32) << 32) | kHoleNanLower32;
1772
1773// ES6 section 20.1.2.6 Number.MAX_SAFE_INTEGER
1774constexpr uint64_t kMaxSafeIntegerUint64 = 9007199254740991; // 2^53-1
1775static_assert(kMaxSafeIntegerUint64 == (uint64_t{1} << 53) - 1);
1776constexpr double kMaxSafeInteger = static_cast<double>(kMaxSafeIntegerUint64);
1777// ES6 section 21.1.2.8 Number.MIN_SAFE_INTEGER
1778constexpr double kMinSafeInteger = -kMaxSafeInteger;
1779
1780constexpr double kMaxUInt32Double = double{kMaxUInt32};
1781
1782// The order of this enum has to be kept in sync with the predicates below.
1783enum class VariableMode : uint8_t {
1784 // User declared variables:
1785 kLet, // declared via 'let' declarations (first lexical)
1786
1787 kConst, // declared via 'const' declarations
1788
1789 kUsing, // declared via 'using' declaration for explicit memory management
1790 // (last lexical)
1791
1792 kVar, // declared via 'var', and 'function' declarations
1793
1794 // Variables introduced by the compiler:
1795 kTemporary, // temporary variables (not user-visible), stack-allocated
1796 // unless the scope as a whole has forced context allocation
1797
1798 kDynamic, // always require dynamic lookup (we don't know
1799 // the declaration)
1800
1801 kDynamicGlobal, // requires dynamic lookup, but we know that the
1802 // variable is global unless it has been shadowed
1803 // by an eval-introduced variable
1804
1805 kDynamicLocal, // requires dynamic lookup, but we know that the
1806 // variable is local and where it is unless it
1807 // has been shadowed by an eval-introduced
1808 // variable
1809
1810 // Variables for private methods or accessors whose access require
1811 // brand check. Declared only in class scopes by the compiler
1812 // and allocated only in class contexts:
1813 kPrivateMethod, // Does not coexist with any other variable with the same
1814 // name in the same scope.
1815
1816 kPrivateSetterOnly, // Incompatible with variables with the same name but
1817 // any mode other than kPrivateGetterOnly. Transition to
1818 // kPrivateGetterAndSetter if a later declaration for the
1819 // same name with kPrivateGetterOnly is made.
1820
1821 kPrivateGetterOnly, // Incompatible with variables with the same name but
1822 // any mode other than kPrivateSetterOnly. Transition to
1823 // kPrivateGetterAndSetter if a later declaration for the
1824 // same name with kPrivateSetterOnly is made.
1825
1826 kPrivateGetterAndSetter, // Does not coexist with any other variable with the
1827 // same name in the same scope.
1828
1829 kLastLexicalVariableMode = kUsing,
1830};
1831
1832// Printing support
1833#ifdef DEBUG
1834inline const char* VariableMode2String(VariableMode mode) {
1835 switch (mode) {
1836 case VariableMode::kVar:
1837 return "VAR";
1838 case VariableMode::kLet:
1839 return "LET";
1840 case VariableMode::kPrivateGetterOnly:
1841 return "PRIVATE_GETTER_ONLY";
1842 case VariableMode::kPrivateSetterOnly:
1843 return "PRIVATE_SETTER_ONLY";
1844 case VariableMode::kPrivateMethod:
1845 return "PRIVATE_METHOD";
1846 case VariableMode::kPrivateGetterAndSetter:
1847 return "PRIVATE_GETTER_AND_SETTER";
1848 case VariableMode::kConst:
1849 return "CONST";
1850 case VariableMode::kDynamic:
1851 return "DYNAMIC";
1852 case VariableMode::kDynamicGlobal:
1853 return "DYNAMIC_GLOBAL";
1854 case VariableMode::kDynamicLocal:
1855 return "DYNAMIC_LOCAL";
1856 case VariableMode::kTemporary:
1857 return "TEMPORARY";
1858 case VariableMode::kUsing:
1859 return "USING";
1860 }
1861 UNREACHABLE();
1862}
1863#endif
1864
1865enum VariableKind : uint8_t {
1866 NORMAL_VARIABLE,
1867 PARAMETER_VARIABLE,
1868 THIS_VARIABLE,
1869 SLOPPY_BLOCK_FUNCTION_VARIABLE,
1870 SLOPPY_FUNCTION_NAME_VARIABLE
1871};
1872
1873inline bool IsDynamicVariableMode(VariableMode mode) {
1874 return mode >= VariableMode::kDynamic && mode <= VariableMode::kDynamicLocal;
1875}
1876
1877inline bool IsDeclaredVariableMode(VariableMode mode) {
1878 static_assert(static_cast<uint8_t>(VariableMode::kLet) ==
1879 0); // Implies that mode >= VariableMode::kLet.
1880 return mode <= VariableMode::kVar;
1881}
1882
1883inline bool IsPrivateAccessorVariableMode(VariableMode mode) {
1884 return mode >= VariableMode::kPrivateSetterOnly &&
1885 mode <= VariableMode::kPrivateGetterAndSetter;
1886}
1887
1888inline bool IsPrivateMethodVariableMode(VariableMode mode) {
1889 return mode == VariableMode::kPrivateMethod;
1890}
1891
1892inline bool IsPrivateMethodOrAccessorVariableMode(VariableMode mode) {
1893 return IsPrivateMethodVariableMode(mode) ||
1894 IsPrivateAccessorVariableMode(mode);
1895}
1896
1897inline bool IsSerializableVariableMode(VariableMode mode) {
1898 return IsDeclaredVariableMode(mode) ||
1899 IsPrivateMethodOrAccessorVariableMode(mode);
1900}
1901
1902inline bool IsImmutableLexicalVariableMode(VariableMode mode) {
1903 return mode == VariableMode::kConst || mode == VariableMode::kUsing;
1904}
1905
1906inline bool IsImmutableLexicalOrPrivateVariableMode(VariableMode mode) {
1907 return IsImmutableLexicalVariableMode(mode) ||
1908 IsPrivateMethodOrAccessorVariableMode(mode);
1909}
1910
1911inline bool IsLexicalVariableMode(VariableMode mode) {
1912 static_assert(static_cast<uint8_t>(VariableMode::kLet) ==
1913 0); // Implies that mode >= VariableMode::kLet.
1914 return mode <= VariableMode::kLastLexicalVariableMode;
1915}
1916
1917enum VariableLocation : uint8_t {
1918 // Before and during variable allocation, a variable whose location is
1919 // not yet determined. After allocation, a variable looked up as a
1920 // property on the global object (and possibly absent). name() is the
1921 // variable name, index() is invalid.
1922 UNALLOCATED,
1923
1924 // A slot in the parameter section on the stack. index() is the
1925 // parameter index, counting left-to-right. The receiver is index -1;
1926 // the first parameter is index 0.
1927 PARAMETER,
1928
1929 // A slot in the local section on the stack. index() is the variable
1930 // index in the stack frame, starting at 0.
1931 LOCAL,
1932
1933 // An indexed slot in a heap context. index() is the variable index in
1934 // the context object on the heap, starting at 0. scope() is the
1935 // corresponding scope.
1936 CONTEXT,
1937
1938 // A named slot in a heap context. name() is the variable name in the
1939 // context object on the heap, with lookup starting at the current
1940 // context. index() is invalid.
1941 LOOKUP,
1942
1943 // A named slot in a module's export table.
1944 MODULE,
1945
1946 // An indexed slot in a script context. index() is the variable
1947 // index in the context object on the heap, starting at 0.
1948 // Important: REPL_GLOBAL variables from different scripts with the
1949 // same name share a single script context slot. Every
1950 // script context will reserve a slot, but only one will be used.
1951 // REPL_GLOBAL variables are stored in script contexts, but accessed like
1952 // globals, i.e. they always require a lookup at runtime to find the right
1953 // script context.
1954 REPL_GLOBAL,
1955
1956 kLastVariableLocation = REPL_GLOBAL
1957};
1958
1959// ES6 specifies declarative environment records with mutable and immutable
1960// bindings that can be in two states: initialized and uninitialized.
1961// When accessing a binding, it needs to be checked for initialization.
1962// However in the following cases the binding is initialized immediately
1963// after creation so the initialization check can always be skipped:
1964//
1965// 1. Var declared local variables.
1966// var foo;
1967// 2. A local variable introduced by a function declaration.
1968// function foo() {}
1969// 3. Parameters
1970// function x(foo) {}
1971// 4. Catch bound variables.
1972// try {} catch (foo) {}
1973// 6. Function name variables of named function expressions.
1974// var x = function foo() {}
1975// 7. Implicit binding of 'this'.
1976// 8. Implicit binding of 'arguments' in functions.
1977//
1978// The following enum specifies a flag that indicates if the binding needs a
1979// distinct initialization step (kNeedsInitialization) or if the binding is
1980// immediately initialized upon creation (kCreatedInitialized).
1981enum InitializationFlag : uint8_t { kNeedsInitialization, kCreatedInitialized };
1982
1983// Static variables can only be used with the class in the closest
1984// class scope as receivers.
1985enum class IsStaticFlag : uint8_t { kNotStatic, kStatic };
1986
1987enum MaybeAssignedFlag : uint8_t { kNotAssigned, kMaybeAssigned };
1988
1989enum class InterpreterPushArgsMode : unsigned {
1990 kArrayFunction,
1991 kWithFinalSpread,
1992 kOther
1993};
1994
1995inline size_t hash_value(InterpreterPushArgsMode mode) {
1996 return base::bit_cast<unsigned>(mode);
1997}
1998
1999inline std::ostream& operator<<(std::ostream& os,
2000 InterpreterPushArgsMode mode) {
2001 switch (mode) {
2002 case InterpreterPushArgsMode::kArrayFunction:
2003 return os << "ArrayFunction";
2004 case InterpreterPushArgsMode::kWithFinalSpread:
2005 return os << "WithFinalSpread";
2006 case InterpreterPushArgsMode::kOther:
2007 return os << "Other";
2008 }
2009 UNREACHABLE();
2010}
2011
2012inline uint32_t ObjectHash(Address address) {
2013 // All objects are at least pointer aligned, so we can remove the trailing
2014 // zeros.
2015 return static_cast<uint32_t>(address >> kTaggedSizeLog2);
2016}
2017
2018// Type feedback is encoded in such a way that, we can combine the feedback
2019// at different points by performing an 'OR' operation. Type feedback moves
2020// to a more generic type when we combine feedback.
2021//
2022// kSignedSmall -> kSignedSmallInputs -> kNumber -> kNumberOrOddball -> kAny
2023// kString -> kAny
2024// kBigInt64 -> kBigInt -> kAny
2025//
2026// Technically we wouldn't need the separation between the kNumber and the
2027// kNumberOrOddball values here, since for binary operations, we always
2028// truncate oddballs to numbers. In practice though it causes TurboFan to
2029// generate quite a lot of unused code though if we always handle numbers
2030// and oddballs everywhere, although in 99% of the use sites they are only
2031// used with numbers.
2032class BinaryOperationFeedback {
2033 public:
2034 enum {
2035 kNone = 0x0,
2036 kSignedSmall = 0x1,
2037 kSignedSmallInputs = 0x3,
2038 kNumber = 0x7,
2039 kNumberOrOddball = 0xF,
2040 kString = 0x10,
2041 kBigInt64 = 0x20,
2042 kBigInt = 0x60,
2043 kStringWrapper = 0x80,
2044 kStringOrStringWrapper = 0x90,
2045 kAny = 0x7F
2046 };
2047};
2048
2049// Type feedback is encoded in such a way that, we can combine the feedback
2050// at different points by performing an 'OR' operation.
2051// This is distinct from BinaryOperationFeedback on purpose, because the
2052// feedback that matters differs greatly as well as the way it is consumed.
2053class CompareOperationFeedback {
2054 enum {
2055 kSignedSmallFlag = 1 << 0,
2056 kOtherNumberFlag = 1 << 1,
2057 kBooleanFlag = 1 << 2,
2058 kNullOrUndefinedFlag = 1 << 3,
2059 kInternalizedStringFlag = 1 << 4,
2060 kOtherStringFlag = 1 << 5,
2061 kSymbolFlag = 1 << 6,
2062 kBigInt64Flag = 1 << 7,
2063 kOtherBigIntFlag = 1 << 8,
2064 kReceiverFlag = 1 << 9,
2065 kAnyMask = 0x3FF,
2066 };
2067
2068 public:
2069 enum Type {
2070 kNone = 0,
2071
2072 kBoolean = kBooleanFlag,
2073 kNullOrUndefined = kNullOrUndefinedFlag,
2074 kOddball = kBoolean | kNullOrUndefined,
2075
2076 kSignedSmall = kSignedSmallFlag,
2077 kNumber = kSignedSmall | kOtherNumberFlag,
2078 kNumberOrBoolean = kNumber | kBoolean,
2079 kNumberOrOddball = kNumber | kOddball,
2080
2081 kInternalizedString = kInternalizedStringFlag,
2082 kString = kInternalizedString | kOtherStringFlag,
2083
2084 kReceiver = kReceiverFlag,
2085 kReceiverOrNullOrUndefined = kReceiver | kNullOrUndefined,
2086
2087 kBigInt64 = kBigInt64Flag,
2088 kBigInt = kBigInt64Flag | kOtherBigIntFlag,
2089 kSymbol = kSymbolFlag,
2090
2091 kAny = kAnyMask,
2092 };
2093};
2094
2095// Type feedback is encoded in such a way that, we can combine the feedback
2096// at different points by performing an 'OR' operation. Type feedback moves
2097// to a more generic type when we combine feedback.
2098// kNone -> kEnumCacheKeysAndIndices -> kEnumCacheKeys -> kAny
2099enum class ForInFeedback : uint8_t {
2100 kNone = 0x0,
2101 kEnumCacheKeysAndIndices = 0x1,
2102 kEnumCacheKeys = 0x3,
2103 kAny = 0x7
2104};
2105static_assert((static_cast<int>(ForInFeedback::kNone) |
2106 static_cast<int>(ForInFeedback::kEnumCacheKeysAndIndices)) ==
2107 static_cast<int>(ForInFeedback::kEnumCacheKeysAndIndices));
2108static_assert((static_cast<int>(ForInFeedback::kEnumCacheKeysAndIndices) |
2109 static_cast<int>(ForInFeedback::kEnumCacheKeys)) ==
2110 static_cast<int>(ForInFeedback::kEnumCacheKeys));
2111static_assert((static_cast<int>(ForInFeedback::kEnumCacheKeys) |
2112 static_cast<int>(ForInFeedback::kAny)) ==
2113 static_cast<int>(ForInFeedback::kAny));
2114
2115enum class UnicodeEncoding : uint8_t {
2116 // Different unicode encodings in a |word32|:
2117 UTF16, // hi 16bits -> trailing surrogate or 0, low 16bits -> lead surrogate
2118 UTF32, // full UTF32 code unit / Unicode codepoint
2119};
2120
2121inline size_t hash_value(UnicodeEncoding encoding) {
2122 return static_cast<uint8_t>(encoding);
2123}
2124
2125inline std::ostream& operator<<(std::ostream& os, UnicodeEncoding encoding) {
2126 switch (encoding) {
2127 case UnicodeEncoding::UTF16:
2128 return os << "UTF16";
2129 case UnicodeEncoding::UTF32:
2130 return os << "UTF32";
2131 }
2132 UNREACHABLE();
2133}

2220#define TIERING_STATE_LIST(V) \
2221 V(None, 0b000) \
2222 V(InProgress, 0b001) \
2223 V(RequestMaglev_Synchronous, 0b010) \
2224 V(RequestMaglev_Concurrent, 0b011) \
2225 V(RequestTurbofan_Synchronous, 0b100) \
2226 V(RequestTurbofan_Concurrent, 0b101)
2227
2228enum class TieringState : int32_t {
2229#define V(Name, Value) k##Name = Value,
2230 TIERING_STATE_LIST(V)
2231#undef V
2232 kLastTieringState = kRequestTurbofan_Concurrent,
2233};
2234
2235// The state kInProgress (= an optimization request for this function is
2236// currently being serviced) currently means that no other tiering action can
2237// happen. Define this constant so we can static_assert it at related code
2238// sites.
2239static constexpr bool kTieringStateInProgressBlocksTierup = true;
2240
2241// To efficiently check whether a marker is kNone or kInProgress using a single
2242// mask, we expect the kNone to be 0 and kInProgress to be 1 so that we can
2243// mask off the lsb for checking.
2244static_assert(static_cast<int>(TieringState::kNone) == 0b00 &&
2245 static_cast<int>(TieringState::kInProgress) == 0b01);
2246static_assert(static_cast<int>(TieringState::kLastTieringState) <= 0b111);
2247static constexpr uint32_t kNoneOrInProgressMask = 0b110;
2248
2249#define V(Name, Value) \
2250 constexpr bool Is##Name(TieringState state) { \
2251 return state == TieringState::k##Name; \
2252 }
2253TIERING_STATE_LIST(V)
2254#undef V
2255
2256constexpr bool IsRequestMaglev(TieringState state) {
2257 return IsRequestMaglev_Concurrent(state) ||
2258 IsRequestMaglev_Synchronous(state);
2259}
2260constexpr bool IsRequestTurbofan(TieringState state) {
2261 return IsRequestTurbofan_Concurrent(state) ||
2262 IsRequestTurbofan_Synchronous(state);
2263}
2264
2265constexpr const char* ToString(TieringState marker) {
2266 switch (marker) {
2267#define V(Name, Value) \
2268 case TieringState::k##Name: \
2269 return "TieringState::k" #Name;
2270 TIERING_STATE_LIST(V)
2271#undef V
2272 }
2273}
2274
2275inline std::ostream& operator<<(std::ostream& os, TieringState marker) {
2276 return os << ToString(marker);
2277}
2278
2279#undef TIERING_STATE_LIST
2280
2281// State machine:
2282// S(tate)0: kPending
2283// S1: kEarlyMaglev
2284// S2: kEarlyTurbofan
2285// S3: kNormal
2286//
2287// C(ondition)0: maglev compile
2288// C1: ic was stable early
2289// C2: turbofan compile
2290// C3: ic change or deopt
2291//
2292// S0 -- C0 -- C1 --> S1 -- C2 -- C3 --> S2 --|
2293// | | |
2294// | |-----------------------|
2295// | |
2296// | C3
2297// | |
2298// |-----------------------> S3
2299enum class CachedTieringDecision : int32_t {
2300 kPending,
2301 kEarlyMaglev,
2302 kEarlyTurbofan,
2303 kNormal,
2304};

2311 switch (speculation_mode) {
2312 case SpeculationMode::kAllowSpeculation:
2313 return os << "SpeculationMode::kAllowSpeculation";
2314 case SpeculationMode::kDisallowSpeculation:
2315 return os << "SpeculationMode::kDisallowSpeculation";
2316 }
2317}

2342// An architecture independent representation of the sets of registers available
2343// for instruction creation.
2344enum class AliasingKind {
2345 // Registers alias a single register of every other size (e.g. Intel).
2346 kOverlap,
2347 // Registers alias two registers of the next smaller size (e.g. ARM).
2348 kCombine,
2349 // SIMD128 Registers are independent of every other size (e.g Riscv)
2350 kIndependent
2351};

2396enum class KeyedAccessLoadMode {
2397 kInBounds = 0b00,
2398 kHandleOOB = 0b01,
2399 kHandleHoles = 0b10,
2400 kHandleOOBAndHoles = 0b11,
2401};
2402
2403inline KeyedAccessLoadMode CreateKeyedAccessLoadMode(bool handle_oob,
2404 bool handle_holes) {
2405 return static_cast<KeyedAccessLoadMode>(
2406 static_cast<int>(handle_oob) | (static_cast<int>(handle_holes) << 1));
2407}
2408
2409inline KeyedAccessLoadMode GeneralizeKeyedAccessLoadMode(
2410 KeyedAccessLoadMode mode1, KeyedAccessLoadMode mode2) {
2411 using T = std::underlying_type<KeyedAccessLoadMode>::type;
2412 return static_cast<KeyedAccessLoadMode>(static_cast<T>(mode1) |
2413 static_cast<T>(mode2));
2414}
2415
2416inline bool LoadModeHandlesOOB(KeyedAccessLoadMode load_mode) {
2417 using T = std::underlying_type<KeyedAccessLoadMode>::type;
2418 return (static_cast<T>(load_mode) &
2419 static_cast<T>(KeyedAccessLoadMode::kHandleOOB)) != 0;
2420}
2421
2422inline bool LoadModeHandlesHoles(KeyedAccessLoadMode load_mode) {
2423 using T = std::underlying_type<KeyedAccessLoadMode>::type;
2424 return (static_cast<T>(load_mode) &
2425 static_cast<T>(KeyedAccessLoadMode::kHandleHoles)) != 0;
2426}
2427
2428enum class KeyedAccessStoreMode {
2429 kInBounds,
2430 kGrowAndHandleCOW,
2431 kIgnoreTypedArrayOOB,
2432 kHandleCOW,
2433};
2434
2435inline std::ostream& operator<<(std::ostream& os, KeyedAccessStoreMode mode) {
2436 switch (mode) {
2437 case KeyedAccessStoreMode::kInBounds:
2438 return os << "kInBounds";
2439 case KeyedAccessStoreMode::kGrowAndHandleCOW:
2440 return os << "kGrowAndHandleCOW";
2441 case KeyedAccessStoreMode::kIgnoreTypedArrayOOB:
2442 return os << "kIgnoreTypedArrayOOB";
2443 case KeyedAccessStoreMode::kHandleCOW:
2444 return os << "kHandleCOW";
2445 }
2446 UNREACHABLE();
2447}

2449enum MutableMode { MUTABLE, IMMUTABLE };
2450
2451inline bool StoreModeIsInBounds(KeyedAccessStoreMode store_mode) {
2452 return store_mode == KeyedAccessStoreMode::kInBounds;
2453}
2454
2455inline bool StoreModeHandlesCOW(KeyedAccessStoreMode store_mode) {
2456 return store_mode == KeyedAccessStoreMode::kHandleCOW ||
2457 store_mode == KeyedAccessStoreMode::kGrowAndHandleCOW;
2458}
2459
2460inline bool StoreModeSupportsTypeArray(KeyedAccessStoreMode store_mode) {
2461 return store_mode == KeyedAccessStoreMode::kInBounds ||
2462 store_mode == KeyedAccessStoreMode::kIgnoreTypedArrayOOB;
2463}
2464
2465inline bool StoreModeIgnoresTypeArrayOOB(KeyedAccessStoreMode store_mode) {
2466 return store_mode == KeyedAccessStoreMode::kIgnoreTypedArrayOOB;
2467}
2468
2469inline bool StoreModeCanGrow(KeyedAccessStoreMode store_mode) {
2470 return store_mode == KeyedAccessStoreMode::kGrowAndHandleCOW;
2471}

2475// Helper stubs can be called in different ways depending on where the target
2476// code is located and how the call sequence is expected to look like:
2477// - CodeObject: Call on-heap {Code} object via {RelocInfo::CODE_TARGET}.
2478// - WasmRuntimeStub: Call native {WasmCode} stub via
2479// {RelocInfo::WASM_STUB_CALL}.
2480// - BuiltinPointer: Call a builtin based on a builtin pointer with dynamic
2481// contents. If builtins are embedded, we call directly into off-heap code
2482// without going through the on-heap Code trampoline.
2483enum class StubCallMode {
2484 kCallCodeObject,
2485#if V8_ENABLE_WEBASSEMBLY
2486 kCallWasmRuntimeStub,
2487#endif // V8_ENABLE_WEBASSEMBLY
2488 kCallBuiltinPointer,
2489};

2501constexpr int kJSArgcReceiverSlots = 1;

2504// Helper to get the parameter count for functions with JS linkage.
2505inline constexpr int JSParameterCount(int param_count_without_receiver) {
2506 return param_count_without_receiver + kJSArgcReceiverSlots;
2507}

2509// A special {Parameter} index for JSCalls that represents the closure.
2510// The constant is defined here for accessibility (without having to include TF
2511// internals), even though it is mostly relevant to Turbofan.
2512constexpr int kJSCallClosureParameterIndex = -1;
2513constexpr int kMinParameterIndex = kJSCallClosureParameterIndex;
2514
2515// Opaque data type for identifying stack frames. Used extensively
2516// by the debugger.
2517// ID_MIN_VALUE and ID_MAX_VALUE are specified to ensure that enumeration type
2518// has correct value range (see Issue 830 for more details).
2519enum StackFrameId { ID_MIN_VALUE = kMinInt, ID_MAX_VALUE = kMaxInt, NO_ID = 0 };
2520
2521enum class ExceptionStatus : bool { kException = false, kSuccess = true };
2522V8_INLINE bool operator!(ExceptionStatus status) {
2523 return !static_cast<bool>(status);
2524}

2526enum class TraceRetainingPathMode { kEnabled, kDisabled };

2528// Used in the ScopeInfo flags fields for the function name variable for named
2529// function expressions, and for the receiver. Must be declared here so that it
2530// can be used in Torque.
2531enum class VariableAllocationInfo { NONE, STACK, CONTEXT, UNUSED };

2533#ifdef V8_COMPRESS_POINTERS
2534class PtrComprCageBase {
2535 public:
2536 explicit constexpr PtrComprCageBase(Address address) : address_(address) {}
2537 // NOLINTNEXTLINE
2538 inline PtrComprCageBase(const Isolate* isolate);
2539 // NOLINTNEXTLINE
2540 inline PtrComprCageBase(const LocalIsolate* isolate);
2541
2542 inline Address address() const { return address_; }
2543
2544 bool operator==(const PtrComprCageBase& other) const {
2545 return address_ == other.address_;
2546 }
2547
2548 private:
2549 Address address_;
2550};
2551#else
2552class PtrComprCageBase {
2553 public:
2554 explicit constexpr PtrComprCageBase(Address address) {}
2555 PtrComprCageBase() = default;
2556 // NOLINTNEXTLINE
2557 PtrComprCageBase(const Isolate* isolate) {}
2558 // NOLINTNEXTLINE
2559 PtrComprCageBase(const LocalIsolate* isolate) {}
2560};
2561#endif
2562
2563class int31_t {
2564 public:
2565 constexpr int31_t() : value_(0) {}
2566 constexpr int31_t(int value) : value_(value) { // NOLINT(runtime/explicit)
2567 DCHECK_EQ((value & 0x80000000) != 0, (value & 0x40000000) != 0);
2568 }
2569 int31_t& operator=(int value) {
2570 DCHECK_EQ((value & 0x80000000) != 0, (value & 0x40000000) != 0);
2571 value_ = value;
2572 return *this;
2573 }
2574 int32_t value() const { return value_; }
2575 operator int32_t() const { return value_; }
2576
2577 private:
2578 int32_t value_;
2579};

2581enum PropertiesEnumerationMode {
2582 // String and then Symbol properties according to the spec
2583 // ES#sec-object.assign
2584 kEnumerationOrder,
2585 // Order of property addition
2586 kPropertyAdditionOrder,
2587};
2588
2589enum class StringTransitionStrategy {
2590 // The string must be transitioned to a new representation by first copying.
2591 kCopy,
2592 // The string can be transitioned in-place by changing its map.
2593 kInPlace,
2594 // The string is already transitioned to the desired representation.
2595 kAlreadyTransitioned
2596};

2600// Tag dispatching support for atomic loads and stores.
2601struct AcquireLoadTag {};
2602struct RelaxedLoadTag {};
2603struct ReleaseStoreTag {};
2604struct RelaxedStoreTag {};
2605struct SeqCstAccessTag {};

2607static constexpr RelaxedLoadTag kRelaxedLoad;
2608static constexpr ReleaseStoreTag kReleaseStore;
2609static constexpr RelaxedStoreTag kRelaxedStore;
2610static constexpr SeqCstAccessTag kSeqCstAccess;
